column1: Ipswich Town beat AZ Alkmaar in the cup final, with the second leg ending in defeat for the Dutch team. Butcher, who played in the winning team, was part of a cycling team that made a 260-mile trip to Holland to commemorate the victory. The team raised money for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Several storms caused damage in the area, resulting in severe flooding in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles. The full cost of repairing the damage has not been calculated, but the council will receive support from the Bellwin Scheme. However, the local authority will have to contribute 0.2% of their net revenue budget, which translates to £508,000. A report to members of the council's executive committee outlined 240 pieces of work, including 114 classified as major, that need to be undertaken to repair the damage. The report does not include further works that might be necessary after bridges are examined below the water level.

Thomas Cook Airlines will operate a weekly flight between Glasgow and Las Vegas next summer, using its Airbus A330 fleet. The flight will operate from May to October, and Glasgow Airport is thrilled to offer this new route to Scotland for the first time. The airline is also adding an additional flight to Tunisia three times a week in the summer of 2015.

England's national football team, led by Roy Hodgson, will face Italy, the Czech Republic, and either Wales or Northern Ireland in the group stage of the UEFA European Football Championship. The Republic of Ireland, if they win their play-off, will face potential opponents such as the Czech Republic or Northern Ireland in the group stage. The seedings for the draw are based on Uefa's national team coefficient rankings. The finals, held by France, will also include Spain, Germany, Portugal, and Belgium as top seeds. Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ukraine, Sweden, and Hungary are also in the play-off draw. The play-offs will determine the final 24 teams participating in the tournament. The finals draw will be held on December 12, 2022.

Damon Smith admitted to perpetrating a bomb hoax by planting an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) on a Jubilee Line train. The device contained ball bearings to act as shrapnel, and the prosecution claims he intended for it to explode and endanger lives. Smith claimed he only intended for the device to produce smoke, but added the ball bearings later to create a real bomb. The court heard that Smith has Asperger's syndrome and an interest in weapons. The trial continues.

Developers Lindhurst Group won approval for £250m housing scheme in Mansfield, but faced opposition. Vote was split, with chairman having casting vote in favour. Project will bring 4,000 jobs and new primary school, community centre, and park, but critics raised concerns about congestion and habitat loss.
UN report says Europe has worst record of throwing away fish. Almost 25% of catches are discarded due to unwanted species.

In 2011, HP acquired Palm, the maker of the WebOS operating system, for $1.2 billion. However, HP has not recouped much of the money it paid for Palm, and the financial details of the deal have not been disclosed. LG has now acquired the WebOS code from HP to use in its next-generation smart TV technology. The deal includes engineers and documentation related to the WebOS. HP is retaining the underlying patents and technology that connect to web-based services. LG was one of the first companies to work on the WebOS code, leading to the acquisition. The use of WebOS in TVs makes sense for LG, as it could lead to a return to the software's roots in smartphones. The acquisition is likely driven by LG's recognition of the need to differentiate through software-based innovation in user experience. HP has also announced its first Android-powered tablet, the HP Slate 7, at the 2013 Mobile World Congress.

Ipswich Town's manager, Mick McCarthy, is unhappy with his team's performance in a pre-season friendly against Bury. Joe Pigott scored an equalizer in the 89th minute after Andre Dozzell opened the scoring for Ipswich. McCarthy criticized his team's defending, saying he's "fuming" and "not tolerating" the team's mistakes. He also pointed to examples of late goals conceded in previous seasons, which cost Ipswich points.

Jane Austen's glasses, kept in her writing desk, were tested at the British Library. Results showed they increased in strength and may have contributed to her early death from poisoning caused by heavy metals like arsenic in medicines she may have taken for rheumatism. The cause of her death has been the subject of speculation.

Justin Welby, Archbishop of Canterbury, announced a plan to fix Easter Sunday as the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April, the date specified by an act of Parliament in 1928. However, the plan has not yet been implemented due to disagreements among Christian churches. Welby is in talks with Pope Francis, Coptic leader Pope Tawadros, and the leader of the Orthodox church to try to reach an agreement. He hopes to see the change within 5-10 years. There have been previous attempts to agree on a common Easter date since the 10th century, but no success has been reached yet.

The latest survey of business conditions in Northern Ireland shows a modest deterioration in activity, with output and new orders declining after growth in March. The private sector's modest decline compares with growth in other UK regions, but manufacturing remains a bright spot. Retailers reported their sharpest decline in sales since 2012, and the construction sector posted its largest fall in business activity in two years. Despite the apparent weakness, companies are continuing to hire staff. The new Conservative government's fiscal plans and economic policies will affect all sectors of the economy.
UKIP spokesman confirms no eggs have been thrown at posters of Farage and John Rees-Evans since they were put up in December.

On Tuesday, the Theatre Royal in Windsor was evacuated due to flash flooding during the opening night of "One Man, Two Guvnors." The performance was halted, but the theatre has since been dried out and the next show is planned to continue as planned. Some attendees described seeing water pouring into the auditorium.

Fiji has faced political upheaval since independence from Britain in 1970 due to rivalry between the indigenous Fijian and ethnic Indian communities. In 2014, Frank Bainimarama became prime minister following a coup and is the first non-indigenous president elected by parliament. The president, Jioji Konousi Konrote, is the first non-indigenous president and was elected by parliament in October 2015. Bainimarama is also an indigenous Fijian and has championed equal rights for the ethnic Indian community. Since 2012, the government has controlled the media through the Fiji Media Industry Development Authority, leading to self-censorship. Key dates include Dutch explorer Abel Tasman visiting the islands in 1643 and Fiji's independence in 1970.

Two students, Ruby Rai and Saurabh Shrestha, who excelled in their exams, had their results suspended due to a viral video of Ruby's interview where she mentioned cooking as a political science topic. The Bihar government announced tough measures to curb cheating but the lower pass rate was an indication that the steps worked until the video was aired. The students will now have to appear for a written test and interview.

About 30 people had been living in tents outside the Central Library in St Peter's Square since April 15th. Manchester City Council issued a warrant to close the camp, and the protesters lost an appeal. They have now set up another settlement in St Anne's Square. Police and bailiffs arrived to break up the St Peter's Square camp, and some protesters left peacefully while others resisted. The council said some demonstrators had been behaving inappropriately in a public area. The council has spent more than £88,000 on additional policing, security, and legal costs.

Two pieces of debris from missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 have been found in Mozambique and flown to Australia for analysis. The minister of transport said the finds are consistent with drift modeling of how debris from the missing plane may have been carried by ocean currents. The fate of the plane remains one of aviation's biggest unsolved mysteries. The search for the plane in the Indian Ocean is focusing on the right place and will continue, but the three countries involved expect to end the operation once the area has been fully searched.

The RMT union is planning two more days of strike action in a dispute with ScotRail over driver-only trains. Labour has called on Humza Yousaf to meet with both sides to end the stalemate. Transport Scotland says the minister has already engaged with both sides to find a solution, and has urged the RMT to return to the negotiating table. The RMT plans to hold two more 24-hour strikes, and Labour has said that ScotRail passengers have already faced significant disruption this summer due to infrastructure work. The new UK transport secretary has said resolving the dispute on Southern Railways is his top priority.

Golden State leads 2-1 in the series against Cleveland. Kyrie Irving scored 30 points for the Cavs while Steph Curry had 19 for the Warriors. Coach Steve Kerr said the Warriors were not prepared, and the Cavs punched them in the mouth. LeBron James said his teammates encouraged him to be aggressive and he responded with 35 points. Game four is in Cleveland on Friday.

Lady Gaga's "Applause" was the second highest new entry at number five on the UK Top 40 Singles chart. The track sold 117,000 copies, surpassing its closest competitor, Avicii's "Wake Me Up". "Applause" was released midweek after leaking online. Goulding's previous highest charting single was her cover of Elton John's "Your Song", which peaked at number two in 2010. Her album "Halcyon" climbed seven places to number 19 in the UK Top 40 Albums chart. Lady Gaga said, "It means the world to me to be number one at the moment."

£1.3m of planned cuts to services will be avoided, but the council will make savings through changes to sickness absence policies and energy incentives in schools. A proposal to cut the pay of senior councillors was rejected. The ruling group, made up of independent councillors, proposed cuts to deprived areas, street cleansing, homeless support, women's aid groups, and the Blas Music Festival, claiming the council tax freeze forced the cuts. Highland Council leader Margaret Davidson said not being able to raise funds from a tax increase would result in job cuts and service cuts.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn claimed he was unfairly dismissed from his job as a gardening supervisor at HMP Littlehey after leading worship services that included a Bible passage condemning homosexuality. A gay prisoner and others complained, and he was accused of making a homophobic statement. Trayhorn argued that he was not removed from his volunteer role at the chapel because of his Christian faith, but because a gay prisoner was upset.

The independent inspector of immigration, John Vine, said the Home Office must improve its handling of foreign nationals who have been refused leave to stay in the UK. Mr Vine found that Capita, a private outsourcing group contracted by the Home Office to review and close migration refusal records, had significant inaccuracies in its classification of these records. The report suggests that the number of "overstayers" in the UK is not increasing, but room for improvement exists in the Home Office's handling of these cases. Immigration Minister James Brokenshire said changes made by the government have been having a positive impact and need to be judged over time.

The My Dentist practice in Dolgellau will close on 31 March. The town's other practice is private. The NHS practice could not recruit a permanent dentist in 2 years. The deputy mayor says more needs to be done. The clinical director of My Dentist says there is a shortage of dentists in rural Wales. Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board plans to re-commission dental services in the area.

Liam Day, 26, is missing after climbing alone near Durlston Country Park on Tuesday. An extensive air, sea, and land search is underway, but the search has been suspended for now. His partner, Emily Brown, has posted on Facebook expressing concern for his safety. Climbing equipment was found west of Anvil Point on Wednesday. Police are appealing for information and have enquiries ongoing.

Donegal manager, Michael McGuinness, has devised a strategy to combat the all-attacking style of the defending champions in their All-Ireland semi-final against Dublin. McGuinness trusts his football players to execute their roles and is not concerned about being ranked as underdogs.

About 1,000 graduates turned down job offers in 2015, leaving employers searching for replacements. The number of graduates hired rose 3.3% in 2015 with starting salary at the UK's leading employers remaining at about £30,000 for the second year running, but pay at top law firms, investment banks, and accounting firms increased further.

A man suffered head and leg injuries when he fell in front of an oncoming train at a London train station. He was not critically injured and was later taken to the hospital. The train was slowing down at the time of the incident, and the station was evacuated while the man was treated. Services between the station and London Waterloo were suspended during the incident but later resumed. The British Transport Police are investigating the circumstances surrounding the incident.

Malta is an island in the Mediterranean Sea, with a history of colonial control spanning centuries. It has been occupied by various civilizations, including Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, and later France and Britain. Malta gained independence from Britain in 1964 and is now a popular tourist destination. The Maltese people are predominantly Christian and the island's currency is the euro. Malta's president is Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca and its prime minister is Joseph Muscat. Many of Malta's newspapers and broadcasters have strong political affiliations.

A successful investment banker rebuilds his life after his wife's death in Demolition, directed by Jean-Marc Vallee and starring Gyllenhaal, Watts, and Chris Cooper. The film premieres at TIFF, with Vallee saying it's "probably the most rock 'n' roll film" he's made. Michael Moore's first film in six years, Where to Invade Next, also premieres. TIFF is the start of awards season and last year's winner was The Imitation Game.

The Belfast Telegraph leads with a story about a boy who survived a petrol bomb attack and has scars from surgery that were burned by flames. The Irish News reports on controversy over a Stormont scheme that has awarded grants to five Orange Halls, with nationalists criticizing the funding. The News Letter reports on a prosecution decision in the Kingsmills massacre case and an upcoming inquest delay.

A poll by Action on Hearing Loss found that 30% of people would ignore the "safe level" on their music players, increasing their risk of tinnitus. DJ Paul Oakenfold urged people to wear ear defenders and turn down the volume. One in five people surveyed would not do anything differently to protect their hearing. Tinnitus affects 10% of people in the UK, causing anxiety and feelings of helplessness. Current treatments are limited, and Action on Hearing Loss is funding research. Paul Oakenfold supports the campaign and encourages use of noise-cancelling headphones.

France beat the United States in the mixed team event of the Hopman Cup, with Richard Gasquet and Kristina Mladenovic winning the deciding doubles match. France's only previous win in the competition was in 2014. Great Britain's tennis players Dan Evans and Heather Watson failed to advance to the next round, losing to Switzerland, France, and Germany.

England rugby coach Eddie Jones says he can feel the long-seated rivalry towards Ireland ahead of their match on Saturday, and praises Manu Tuilagi as a potential 12 for England, despite some inconsistencies in his passing. Jones also expects Ireland to kick a lot, but says England will be prepared.

Paramedics in Scotland treated over 12,000 people for alcohol-related issues in the past six months, according to Scottish Conservatives obtained through freedom of information laws. Almost half of all weekend ambulance calls were alcohol-related, with the highest numbers coming from NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, NHS Lothian, and NHS Lanarkshire. The Scottish Ambulance Service spokesman stated that alcohol was a significant factor in their operations and staff safety. Public Health Minister Maureen Watt noted that Scotland was leading the way in taking action to tackle alcohol misuse, but excessive alcohol consumption still places additional pressure on services.

Many people in Northern Ireland don't work, and that's called economic inactivity. The rate is 27%, which is just under the UK average of 22%. The new strategy, "Enabling Success," aims to help people with work-limiting health conditions, lone parents, and those with caring commitments. It will be led by Employment Minister Stephen Farry and Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster. The goal is to increase employment levels to above the UK average by 2030.

Donald Trump criticized John McCain, a former prisoner of war and US senator, for not taking care of veterans. He added that he doesn't like people who were captured. This led to criticism from other Republicans, including rival presidential candidate Rick Perry, who called the remarks a "new low" in US politics. Trump later sought to clarify his remarks and said he respects people who were captured as heroes, but criticized McCain's job performance in the Senate. McCain was held for 5 1/2 years after his plane was shot down in the Vietnam war, while Trump avoided service through student and medical deferments.

Canadian writer and novelist W.P. Kinsella passed away on Friday, with his agent revealing that his death was doctor-assisted. Kinsella was known for his baseball-themed fantasy novel "Shoeless Joe," which was adapted into the film "Field of Dreams." He won the Order of Canada and was best known for his work in fiction and non-fiction. After a car accident, Kinsella stopped writing fiction but later resumed and his final work, "Russian Dolls," is set to be released next year.

Máiría Cahill, a member of one of Ireland's most prominent republican families, won a by-election to fill a seat in the Irish senate left vacant after Jimmy Harte of the Labour party resigned. She is a former member of the Irish republican movement and has accused an IRA member of raping her when she was 16, but he was later acquitted in court. Cahill has since apologized for her involvement in a dissident group and has pledged to use her time in the senate to support victims of abuse and to help change the lives of young jobseekers in Ireland. She won the election with a majority of 122 votes, beating other candidates including Fianna Fáil's Keith Swanick and Sinn Féin's Sinead Burke.

ChildLine has launched a campaign to tackle the number of 12 to 13-year-olds who are worried about being addicted to porn. The charity received separate calls from boys in Cardiff and Prestatyn who said pornography was making them feel perverted and worried about their thoughts. The charity called its campaign the Fight Against Porn Zombies and said a UK-wide poll showed one in five children had seen pornographic images that shocked or upset them. One boy said he was scared it would affect his ability to get married in the future.

Mariner Street car park in Swansea will be cleared and replaced with a 725-bedroom student block, complete with a nightclub, gym, office space, bars, restaurants, and shops. The 22-story tower will be the second tallest building in Swansea, next to Meridian Quay. Construction is expected to start later this year and finish by summer 2018. A report before the planning committee says the tower will be a "bold addition to the city skyline." The project will help High Street's regeneration and build on "the great work that's already been done."

Parts of Queensland and New South Wales are experiencing flooding, caused by torrential rain and the remnants of Cyclone Debbie. Several rivers have breached their banks, prompting emergency warnings, and some towns have been partially submerged. Residents have been captured surveying damage, and businesses have been inundated. The severe weather has also washed away roads and brought down trees, and insurers have not yet estimated the damage bill. Tens of thousands of people lost power, and a bull shark was even spotted in the floods. Fortunately, the storm system has now moved out to sea.

American Airlines experienced a glitch in their iPad software used by pilots and co-pilots, causing some flights to experience issues with their flight plans. The cause of the problem is still being investigated, but it is believed to have been caused by the switch to a paperless cockpit in 2013. The change was made to save money on fuel and to reduce the preparation time for flights. Other airlines, such as United Airlines and Delta, have also made the switch to electronic flight bags.

In 2013, Girish Pote murdered his wife, Madhuvanti Pathak, and chopped her body into pieces. He was convicted by a court in Thane, a Mumbai suburb, and sentenced to life in prison. The judge ruled that Pote would remain in jail for as long as he lived due to the "gruesome" nature of the crime. Pathak held a French passport and the couple had been fighting over money.

Bradford Council is proposing a one-way gyratory system on East Parade, Hanover Street, and Cavendish Street to address the growing congestion problem in the town. The plans will be displayed at the Airedale shopping center on June 11 and 13 for public feedback.

Thorpe, a 23-year-old goalkeeper, has played seven games for Rotherham this season but last appeared in an 5-2 loss to Ipswich on 7 November. He may play for Bradford in their upcoming match against Millwall. Bradford is currently in 7th place in League One, just outside the playoffs.

A prank call was made to Prime Minister Rajoy's office, pretending to be from Carles Puigdemont. The caller was then transferred to the PM himself, who agreed to meet with the fake Puigdemont. Rajoy's party won the most seats in recent elections but fell short of a majority, leaving Spain in political limbo. The prankster later admitted to the hoax, and Rajoy seemed to take it in stride.

The UK government pays immigration detainees £1 an hour to work, but the Labour Party questions the cost savings to the government and the profit for the firms running the centers. The government argues that the work is voluntary and helps detainees relieve boredom.

Seven authors are in the running for the 2017 Walter Scott Prize for historical fiction. The judges extended the list from six to seven titles due to the "variety of the longlist." The shortlisted novels offer "joy in the discovery of unusual subjects" and "appreciation of historical research." The winners will be announced at the Borders Book Festival in Melrose later this year.

England's tour of Bangladesh continues with the second Test in Mirpur. England need 33 runs to win but have only two wickets left. Bangladesh have chased a victory target of 286 in their second innings and both teams have played the game skillfully. The opening Test set a record for the number of decisions reviewed, and England's captain Alastair Cook will decide who will open the batting in the morning.

UCU Scotland members balloted on job security at the University of Aberdeen's medical school, with 75% voting for strike action. A petition will also be handed in on Tuesday, but the university reports that no exams will be disrupted. The university also argues that there will be no need for compulsory redundancies and that the process followed was not discriminatory.
Jay Brenton Liptrot, 43,

A 34-year old man was expected to appear at Aberdeen Sheriff Court for a "disgraceful incident" at the Aberdeen Sea Cadets base at Pocra Quay, but was later freed from custody pending further inquiries.

A coalition of organizations wants all 11-year-olds to be able to read well within a generation, and for parents to read to young children for 10 minutes a day. The report says that children who fall behind in reading can have a negative impact on their lives, and that those from low-income families are less likely to have books at home. The coalition aims to reduce the number of children living in poverty in Scotland and to improve literacy levels. The most commonly read material by children is now text messages, but the report encourages reading books, websites, and e-books.
The Belfast Giants have re-signed forward Matteo
Teenager, Rasmus Barlow, reported missing by father, found dead, not suspicious, family and police supporting family.

A teacher lost her temper and slammed a notebook on a desk, resulting in a ruling that she made contact with a 17-year-old student on the head or hand. The Education Workforce Council ruled that her conduct was unacceptable and will decide whether to strike her off the register at a later date.

Mark Hamill and his family, as well as Darth Vader, are participating in Star Wars Day. Many brands are using the hashtag to sell products such as flight tickets and pizzas. The British Museum is using the day to promote a Star Wars exhibit. Theo Paphitis has also joined in on the fun, and Heathrow Airport is receiving praise for its tweet featuring the Millennium Falcon and X-wing starfighters. Some charities are also using the hashtag to raise awareness.

Retired generals and admirals endorse Republican nominee for president, saying he has the temperament to be commander-in-chief. Donald Trump, who has highlighted veterans' issues during his campaign, calls their support "a great honor". Trump is also criticized for a political donation to a Florida official that led to fraud charges being dropped, and for criticism from military members.

A 21-year-old footballer joined Barnsley last summer from QPR. He had a brief loan spell at Colchester in 2014-15. He signed a one-year contract with a 12-month option at Colchester. The player is a left-sided player.

Phillip Pullman's new trilogy, The Book of Dust, will begin with a novel in October. The first book's title hasn't been revealed yet. His Dark Materials sold over 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages. The new series follows Lyra Belacqua from birth to age 20. Watch the video for more information.

A safety poster with a racially insensitive design depicting more black children as not cool and more white children as cool was criticized on social media. The American Red Cross, which produced the poster, quickly issued an apology and removed it from their website. The Salida Pool and Recreation Department also responded to the criticism.

Karl Robinson will continue as the manager of AFC Wimbledon for the next season, according to the club's owner. He believes Robinson, who led the team to promotion from League One, understands the club better and is committed to improving. The club faced criticism for its recruitment and relegation from the Championship, leading to a discussion between the owner and Robinson. Despite the added pressure, the owner is excited for the team's future in League One.

James Cosmo and Karen Gillan are now honorary patrons of the Edinburgh International Film Festival. Cosmo has starred in films like Braveheart, while Gillan was a former Dr Who star who has now turned to directing. The festival's artistic director, Mark Adams, said he was thrilled to add two Scottish luminaries to the honorary patrons list. Cosmo called it a genuine privilege, while Gillan said she was thrilled to come back to Edinburgh and celebrate Scottish and international filmmaking.

Media playback not supported on device. Spurs underpaid, need to sign well-known players. Rose's comments ill-judged. Pochettino forgives him, Rose has future at Spurs. No signings yet, Walker sold for £45m. Rose wants 2-3 players, apologizes for any offense caused. Rose out with knee injury, Trippier has minor ankle damage.

The International Ski Federation (FIS) banned Mae Vanakorn, a Singapore-born British violinist, for helping to manipulate results to secure her place at the Sochi Olympics. The ban was imposed after an investigation into four Slovenian races before the qualification deadline. Mae, along with five officials, were punished. The Court of Arbitration for Sport will consider the appeal. Mae competed for Thailand at the Olympics under her father's name. She finished last in the Giant Slalom and her ban is being contested.

Eastleigh lost 1-0 to Macclesfield Town in a Football League Two match, with Rhys Browne scoring the only goal of the game in the seventh minute. The visitors had a great start but the game became more open in the first half, with both sides creating chances but unable to find the back of the net. Macclesfield nearly doubled their lead in the second half but the effort was ruled out for offside. The game ended 1-0 in favor of Macclesfield.

The cast of "The Big Bang Theory" has not reached an agreement on salaries with Warner Bros TV, which could delay production. The show has been extended for three more seasons, and the actors are seeking higher pay. If a deal is not reached in the next two weeks, production may be delayed.

Alexander Worth died in a car crash on an access road. Matthew Cobden appeared in court, but only confirmed his identity. He was taken to the hospital with serious injuries. The court expressed sympathy to Alexander's family, who lost their brother in a road traffic accident. The case has been referred to Winchester Crown Court.

Refugees speak out for resettlement in the UK as First Minister Carwyn Jones holds a summit on the refugee crisis in Wales. The Welsh Refugee Council welcomes the UK's decision to resettle 20,000 Syrians, while Methodist minister Paul Martin calls it a "serious disaster." Local authorities in Wales offer to help but ask for financial assistance.

Jhon Jairo Velasquez, known as Popeye, was a hit man for Pablo Escobar and confessed to killing over 300 people. He gave evidence against a former justice minister convicted of ordering a rival's murder. Velasquez was released from prison after serving two decades and is now on probation. Some victims feel he has not paid for his crimes, while others believe it's time for a second chance. He was involved in the murder of presidential hopeful Luis Carlos Galan, who was killed in 1989. Velasquez's testimony helped convict former Justice Minister Alberto Santofimio, who was Escobar's associate.

Wolves' Kurt Gidley wore a camera during a rugby league game, but it was removed at half-time due to technical issues. The coach believes the camera didn't affect Gidley's performance, and the experiment could be continued in the future.

Police were called to Auchinlee care home in Campbeltown on Tuesday after an 82-year-old man was reported to the procurator fiscal for alleged sexual offences against a 76-year-old woman. The Care Inspectorate is working with the police and monitoring the situation closely, and people with concerns about care services can contact their helpline. Police Scotland confirmed that a woman was sexually assaulted by an 82-year-old man in Campbeltown.

A man named Des McDaid, who was from County Donegal in the Republic of Ireland, testified before the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry about his experiences of sexual abuse at the Clontarf orphanage in Perth, Australia when he was eight years old. He said he was sexually abused by older boys, members of the Christian Brothers religious order, and a lay teacher. He also said he was raped by an older boy at the Termonbacca boys home in Derry and was abused by others in Australia. He said he traced his mother when he was 48, but was worried she would not accept him.

The world number 45, Edmund, lost to the reigning US Open champion, Wawrinka, in a three-set match. Wawrinka won in two hours and 36 minutes, breaking serve twice in the decider. The Swiss 31-year-old will play Kei Nishikori in the semi-finals. Milos Raonic, the top seed and defending champion, beat Rafael Nadal 4-6 6-3 6-4 to reach the last four. Raonic will play Grigor Dimitrov, who beat Dominic Thiem. Aljaz Bedene was knocked out in the quarter-finals of the Chennai Open, losing to Benoit Paire 6-3 6-0.

A 50-year-old musician was treated at a neurosurgery clinic in Munich and is expected to stay there for days. The band U2's next US tour date has been postponed, and the Glastonbury appearance may be in doubt. Further information about the impact on other tour dates will be announced. U2's 360 Degree tour was the most profitable in 2009, earning $109 million.

A small plane had an incident near Abergavenny and Raglan, south Wales, at 3:25 PM BST. Two passengers and the pilot were taken to the hospital, and fire crews stopped a fuel leak. The road was closed, and air accident officials were alerted.

Mrs. Scott, a financial expert, is the new chief executive of the city council, replacing Valerie Watts who is leaving to take up an NHS post. She is stepping up to the role from her current position as the council's director of corporate governance. The council leader, Barney Crockett, said they are "absolutely delighted" to have chosen Mrs. Scott. She will use her financial expertise, drive, and leadership to help the administration deliver on its promises to the city. Mrs. Scott is proud to accept the job and is looking forward to working with elected members, colleagues, and key partners to deliver on Aberdeen's priorities. The salary will be Â£144,685.

Manchester United's 21-year-old full-back Matteo Darmian has suffered a dislocated shoulder during a 1-1 draw with Sunderland, leaving the team with no available full-backs. Borthwick-Jackson and Love made their first-team debuts.

Kenneth Harper's convictions for rape were quashed by judges at the Court of Criminal Appeal in Edinburgh due to arguments about mutual corroboration. He was given a three-year sentence for the remaining offences. The court found that there were no compelling similarities between two incidents that occurred eight years apart, and there were no extraordinary features linking the two cases.

Actor Michael Broadbent will portray Tommy Butler in "The Great Train Robbery: A Copper's Tale," a drama following "A Robber's Tale" which will be released later this year. "I have such strong memories of the massive impact of the actual robbery," said Broadbent, who won an Oscar and Bafta for previous roles. "It is wonderful to find out from the script so much of the real story."

Lithuanian schoolgirl attacked in Central Park, Peterborough. Mother posts video of fight on Facebook, which has been viewed over 680,000 times. Police investigating. Group of girls beat up the victim, who was left bruised, and said they were angry because she was "being cheeky" to them at school.

The Maccabees scored their first number one album with Marks To Prove It, beating out Lianne La Havas by just 1,300 sales. Cilla Black's album The Very Best of Cilla Black reached its highest chart position in 51 years following her death. Calvin Harris and Disciples' How Deep Is Your Love climbed to number two, while Little Mix's Black Magic fell to number three. The top five was completed by Lost Frequencies' Are You With Me and Years & Years' Shine. The Maccabees narrowly missed out on the number one spot, finishing just 1,300 sales ahead of La Havas.

One Direction continue as a four-piece after Zayn Malik's departure. Liam Payne thanks fans for their support, saying they are the "real heroes". The band plays concerts in South Africa and starts the European leg of their tour in Cardiff. Zayn was reportedly upset and is working on a solo album.

Police Scotland are investigating a social media post that revealed the names and details of alleged gunshot victims. The post has been made aware to the police, who are conducting inquiries into the full circumstances.
A man broke into a stadium and stole keys and cash. He was caught after a cleaner noticed the alarm and noticed footprints.

Nigel Farage visited Sleaford to support UKIP candidate Victoria Ayling in a by-election. He was unaware of an error on a UKIP poster with a letter 'n' in the word Hykeham. The constituency is vacant following the resignation of Conservative MP Stephen Phillips, who quit due to policy differences with the government. There are several candidates running in the Sleaford and North Hykeham by-election.

Stirling County went ahead after 24 seconds when Blair Henderson scored from Michael McKenna's cross. They had a chance to equalize but Moses Olanrewaju's header was blocked by Johnny Fairbairn. Brian Martin was sent off for handling in the area but Stirling County was unable to score, with Sean Dickson missing the penalty.

Fiona Barnes, who also faked terminal cancer, was jailed for 15 months for theft and perverting justice. She was ordered to pay back £1 and the Space Centre called the ruling an "outrageous insult". The centre was later bought by Creative Support, securing its future.

A 31-year-old footballer named El-Abd has been released by Bristol City and is now joining the Shropshire Football Club. He has a long career history with Brighton and has played for several other teams on loan.

England rugby coach Eddie Jones says his team needs more leaders to win the 2019 World Cup. He thinks players are in sheltered environments like academies and not getting enough exposure to leadership. Jones says he is working on developing more leaders and expects hooker Dylan Hartley, who captained England to an unbeaten year in 2016, to lead the team in the Six Nations if he is fit. He also mentions playmaker Owen Farrell as a strong candidate to replace Hartley if needed.

Somerset County Cricket Club has signed batsman Chris Rogers for the County Championship next season, with skipper Maynard describing him as a "marquee player" and a "huge asset" to the team. Rogers, a left-hander from Sydney, has agreed to bat at three for the summer, replacing the retiring Marcus Trescothick and supporting the opening duo of Tom Abell and Marcus Trescothick. Maynard believes Rogers' experience and determination will help the younger members of the team, and he's looking forward to working with him.

A Range Rover crashed into a property on Hearthcote Road in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, causing structural damage and forcing two people to evacuate. Derbyshire Police are investigating and appealing for witnesses. The road was closed for a short time, and one person suffered minor injuries, but no arrests were made.

Work to demolish a building on Kingsway began in 2015, but was delayed due to the discovery of more asbestos than anticipated. The demolition is expected to be completed by the spring of 2023 as scaffolding supports the exterior demolition. The building's outer structure still stands as part of plans to transform the area into a business district. All internal works have been completed.

Rovers were trailing 2-1 when Grant Hanley's shot crossed the line, but the referee did not award a goal. The referee also ignored appeals. The manager of Rovers, Bowyer, urged the Football League to use goal-line technology like the Premier League. Bowyer thinks it would improve the game and make decisions fairer.

19-year-old defender Kapustka has joined English Premier League champions Leicester City for a reported £7.5m. He has signed a five-year deal and impressed at Euro 2016, playing in four of Poland's matches. Kapustka has joined the Foxes before their friendly against Barcelona in Stockholm. He is Claudio Ranieri's fifth summer signing after goalkeeper Zieler, defender Hernandez, midfielder Mendy, and forward Musa.

The Burrell Collection in Glasgow will close temporarily for a multi-million pound redevelopment, reopening in 2020. The museum is hosting free activities this weekend, including live music, a family ceilidh, and guided tours. Only a fifth of the collection is currently on display due to the need for a new roof. The project is estimated to cost between £60m and £66m and will create two new floors of exhibition space, making 90% of the 8,000 objects viewable to the public. Some works from the collection will be displayed at Kelvingrove Museum and Art Gallery during the refurbishment. The first exhibition, "Burrell at Kelvingrove: Joseph Crawhall," will showcase 23 works by Glasgow Boys artist Joseph Crawhall.

Hundreds of farmers received heating subsidies from a poultry processing company. The finance minister expressed fresh concerns about the operation of the scheme, but the company made no reference to the issue. The company advocated responsible use of heat and submitted cost control proposals that were later withdrawn. The finance minister wants a solution to the RHI scandal, not a botched one.
Man's body found in field near Belsyde Avenue, inquiries ongoing to identify him.

Ipswich Town won the 1978 FA Cup by beating AZ Alkmaar in the final, with the help of player Terry Butcher. He took part in a charity cycling event to commemorate the victory, along with other supporters. They raised money for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Storms Desmond, Eva, Frank, and Gertrude, along with an unnamed storm on January 27th, caused severe flooding in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles. The repairs are still being calculated, but the council will receive support under the Bellwin Scheme. However, they must contribute 0.2% of their net revenue budget, which amounts to £508,000. The executive committee's report outlines 114 major and 126 minor repair works. Further work may be necessary once bridges are examined under water level.

Thomas Cook Airlines will operate a weekly flight between Glasgow and Las Vegas starting in May 2015. The airline will use its Airbus A330 fleet for the route, which will run until October. The addition of the Las Vegas flight is due to positive feedback from past one-off flights to the US. Glasgow Airport welcomes the new service, which is expected to attract tens of millions of visitors annually. Thomas Cook has also announced an additional flight to Tunisia, with three flights a week in the summer of 2015.

Roy Hodgson's team is in pot one, with Wales and Northern Ireland in pot four. If the Republic of Ireland win their play-off, they will be in pot three or four, depending on other results. The potential group for the finals includes England, Euro 2012 finalists Italy, the Czech Republic, and either Wales or Northern Ireland. The seedings are based on Uefa's national team coefficient rankings. The other top seeds are Spain, France, Germany, and Portugal, who will become the number one team in Fifa's rankings. The Republic of Ireland are the top seeds in the play-off draw, with Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ukraine, Sweden, and Hungary as their possible opponents. The finals draw takes place on 12 December.

Damon Smith admitted to perpetrating a bomb hoax by placing an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) on a Jubilee Line train, containing ball bearings to increase the destructive effect. Prosecutors say he intended for the device to explode and endanger people. Smith has Asperger's syndrome, and the court heard he was interested in Islam but did not hold extreme views. He built the device to make it look like a real bomb and get it reported on the news. The trial continues.

Mansfield District Council debated and voted on the £250m Lindhurst scheme, which includes up to 1,700 homes, a school, cemetery, community center, and park on the southern edge of the town. The decision was made five in favor, five against, with the chairman having the casting vote in favor. Protests erupted at the meeting with shouts of "shame." The 169-hectare application is the largest ever submitted to the council and developers claim it will bring major benefits to the local economy, including up to 4,000 jobs. Opposition includes concerns from Nottingham Wildlife Trust and the Ramblers Association over the loss of countryside and habitat. Independent Mansfield councillor Andrew Tristram expressed concerns over congestion and the ability to deliver promised benefits.
Europe has the world's worst record of throwing away fish, with almost a quarter of all catches going back overboard due to crew preferences for different types of fish, according to a UN report.

In 2011, HP acquired the WebOS operating system from veteran gadget maker Palm in a $1.2 billion deal. However, HP has not recouped much of the money spent on Palm, and the deal is believed to have been unsuccessful. LG has acquired the WebOS code, engineers, and documentation from HP for use in its smart TV technology. The deal is seen as an opportunity for LG to re-focus on its smartphone roots and differentiate its devices through software-based innovation in user experience. HP also announced the launch of its first Android-powered tablet, the HP Slate 7, at the 2013 Mobile World Congress in Barcelona. The acquisition of WebOS by LG is seen as a strategic move to create more user-friendly devices in the future.

Ipswich Town manager Mick McCarthy was frustrated with his team's poor defending in a pre-season friendly against Gillingham, resulting in a late equalizer for the opposition. McCarthy emphasized the importance of avoiding late goals in crucial matches and criticized his team for giving away possession leading to the equalizer. He also referred to similar instances of dropped points in the past. Despite his criticism, McCarthy stated that he doesn't care about pre-season friendlies and doesn't like them, but he emphasized the importance of avoiding goals late in matches.

Examinations of three pairs of glasses belonging to Jane Austen revealed a significant decline in the author's vision, with tests showing an increase in strength from +1.75 in the first pair to +4.75 and +5.0 in the final pair. The glasses, made of real tortoiseshell and glass, were kept in Austen's writing desk, and tests showed they remained in good condition despite their age. The use of heavy metals like arsenic in medicines may have contributed to Austen's early death at the age of 41, and the British Library is considering the possibility of arsenic poisoning. Experts suggest the poisoning may have caused cataracts, which can affect vision. The glasses' strength and the possibility of accidental poisoning with arsenic are being examined by optometrists and the British Library.

Archbishop Justin Welby announced that Easter, the most important Christian festival, will be fixed on the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April, following a meeting of primates from the Anglican Communion in Canterbury. This has never been activated due to a 1928 UK act, but the archbishop is in talks with Pope Francis, Coptic leader Pope Tawadros, and the leader of the Orthodox church to make this change happen in 5-10 years. There have been 15 attempts to agree on a common date since the 10th Century. Easter is currently celebrated between March 22 and April 25, but the Orthodox church follows the Julian calendar, resulting in later celebrations. In 1990, the Vatican approved a fixed date, but agreement has not been reached.

Ulster Bank's latest survey of Northern Ireland firms showed a modest decline in business activity in April, with output and new orders falling after growth in March. The region's private sector activity trailed growth in other UK regions. Manufacturing saw output and new orders rebound to a six-month high, driven by market demand in Great Britain. Retailers reported their sharpest decline in retail sales since May 2012, and the construction sector posted its largest fall in business activity in two years. Despite weakness suggested by the results, companies continued to hire staff, with employment growth reported across all sectors except construction. The new Conservative government's fiscal plans and economic policies will impact all sectors of the economy.

UKIP's Penarth high street shop has been targeted by opponents since opening in November. The party now invites anarchist friends to throw eggs at posters of UKIP leaders Nigel Farage and John Rees-Evans. So far, no eggs have been thrown, according to a UKIP spokesperson.

Windsor's Theatre Royal was evacuated on Tuesday evening due to flash flooding during the opening night of One Man, Two Guvnors. The performance was halted and the auditorium was later dried out. The theatre director stated that Wednesday night's show will proceed as planned. The flood happened after heavy rainfall, causing some people to be trapped in cars by flash flooding in London. The theatre has experienced occasional flooding in the past but nothing as severe as this. The audience described hearing thunder and lightning during the storm.

Fiji has a long-standing rivalry between its indigenous Fijian and ethnic Indian communities that has been a root cause of political upheaval. In 2014, Frank Bainimarama was elected as prime minister after seizing power in a military coup eight years prior. President Jioji Konousi Konrote was elected in 2015, the first non-indigenous president elected by parliament. Bainimarama is an indigenous Fijian and has championed equal rights for the ethnic Indian community. Self-censorship has been implemented in the media due to government controls on publishing material not in the public interest. Some key dates in Fiji's history include independence from Britain in 1970, two coups, and the first election of an ethnic Indian prime minister in 1999.

In India, the government suspended the results of two students, Ruby Rai and Saurabh Shrestha, who excelled in the examination, after a video of their interviews went viral. The video showed Ruby Rai saying that political science was about cooking, and Saurabh Shrestha unable to answer a simple chemistry question. The government said that their results had been suspended with immediate effect, and they will have to appear for a written test and interview before a panel of subject experts on June 3. Their handwriting will be checked to verify if they answered their own questions. The results of the students were suspended due to the cheating scandal.

About 30 people had been living in tents on St Peter's Square for a month, outside the Central Library. Manchester City Council issued a warrant to close the camp, and campaigners lost an appeal. Demonstrators set up another settlement in St Anne's Square. Police and bailiffs arrived to break up the St Peter's Square camp, but some protesters peacefully left while others resisted. Campaigners wanted to highlight temporary housing and homelessness issues, but the council said some protesters had behaved inappropriately in a public area. Deputy Leader of Manchester City Council Bernard Priest said the camp had cost the council and police more than Â£88,000 and their homelessness service had provided support to some camp members.

Two pieces of debris from missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 have been found in Mozambique and Australia, and have been confirmed to be from the Boeing 777 aircraft. The investigation team has concluded that the debris is almost certainly from MH370 and shows that the vast deep-sea search for the plane in the southern Indian Ocean is focusing on the right place. The search will continue for now, but the three countries involved will end the operation once the area has been fully searched.

The RMT union is planning two further 24-hour strikes, on 24 and 31 July, in an ongoing dispute with ScotRail over driver-only trains. The Scottish government has urged the RMT and ScotRail to meet and find a solution, while passengers are advised to check the ScotRail strike information web page before traveling.

In game three of the NBA Finals, the Cleveland Cavaliers faced the Golden State Warriors and lost, with the Warriors leading the series 2-1. Kyrie Irving and LeBron James led the Cavaliers with 30 and 26 points, respectively, but it was not enough to defeat the Warriors' Steph Curry, who scored 19 points. Warriors coach Steve Kerr acknowledged that his team was not prepared for the game and was defeated by the Cavaliers. The next game will be in Cleveland on Friday.

Lady Gaga's "Applause" is the UK's new number one single, selling 117,000 copies according to the Official Charts Company. It was released midweek after leaking online. Miley Cyrus's "We Can't Stop" falls to number three, and Arctic Monkeys and The Wanted also enter the top 20. Richard and Adam Johnson hold on to the top spot for a third week with "The Impossible Dream." Rudimental and Imagine Dragons round out the top five.

The council will avoid £1.3m in planned cuts thanks to savings from changes in sickness absence policy and energy incentives in schools. The Liberal Democrats' proposal to cut senior councillors' pay was rejected, and the SNP councillors vowed to protect funding for services supporting vulnerable people. The council tax freeze forced the ruling group to make cuts, including funding for deprived areas, street cleansing, homeless support, women's aid groups, and the Blas Music Festival. Highland Council leader Margaret Davidson warned of job cuts and service reductions due to the council tax freeze. The budget leader, Bill Fernie, said the council faced "unprecedented challenges" in setting a balanced budget.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn, an ordained Pentecostal Christian minister, told an employment tribunal he had read 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 Verses 9-11, which includes the lines "neither fornicators, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, nor homosexuals, nor sodomites, nor thieves, nor coveters, nor drunkards, nor revilers, nor extortioners will inherit the Kingdom of God," at HMP Littlehey in Cambridgeshire in 2014. He claims he was unfairly dismissed after complaints were made by gay prisoners. The case against the secretary of state for justice continues. Trayhorn, who had been working as a gardening supervisor at the prison, was invited to lead worship once a week from 2012, and often focused on Christian teachings about sin and repentance. He was later told he could no longer volunteer at chapel services and complaints were made about his gardening work. He was signed off work with stress and resigned in November 2014, claiming he had been harassed because of his Christian faith.

The Independent Inspector of Immigration, John Vine, found significant inaccuracies in Capita's classification of migration refusal records, indicating that the number of "overstayers" thought to have departed may have been overestimated by up to 1,140 in 2013-14. The report suggests that the amount of "overstayers" in the UK has remained largely static, with the overall size of the "migration refusal pool" at 173,562 in the three months to June 2021 compared to 174,057 in the same period two years earlier. Immigration Minister James Brokenshire acknowledged the need for improvements but stated that changes made by the government have been having a positive impact and needed to be judged over time. The Home Office signed a contract with private outsourcing group Capita to review and close the records of migrants who had been refused leave to stay in the UK. However, Mr Vine's report concluded that there had been significant inaccuracies in Capita's classification of migration refusal records, with more than a quarter of departures in his sample being incorrectly recorded.

The My Dentist practice in Dolgellau will close on 31 March. The town's other practice is private. The NHS practice has been unable to recruit a permanent dentist for two years. The deputy mayor of Dolgellau says more needs to be done to get dentists into rural areas. The clinical director of My Dentist says there is a shortage of dentists in rural Wales. The Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board says it will re-commission dental services in the area. A Welsh Government spokesman says the funding remains with the health board to re-commission the service. Betsi Cadwaladr UHB has invited applications from dental contractors to ensure NHS services are available in the area. The health board will continue to review and improve access to NHS primary care dental services.

Liam Day, a 26-year-old man from Southampton, is missing after climbing alone near Durlston Country Park on Tuesday. An extensive search involving police and coastguard crews began on Wednesday, but the search was suspended due to darkness. Mr Day's partner, Emily Brown, posted on Facebook that it was likely he would not return. Climbing equipment was found west of Anvil Point during the search.

Tyrone manager Mickey Harte has stressed the importance of trusting his players to execute their game plan against Dublin in the All-Ireland semi-final. Harte believes footballers should be given the freedom to make decisions on the pitch and not rely too heavily on instructions from the sidelines. Despite being underdogs, Harte is focused on his team's preparations and believes that winning in 2012 as underdogs has given his team the confidence to succeed.

In 2015, around 1,000 graduates turned down job offers at the last minute, leaving employers scrambling for replacements. The High Fliers market research firm found that about 20,000 students were recruited, mostly in their final year of college. This gives graduates time to explore other job opportunities if they become available. High Fliers' managing director, Martin Birchall, noted that at the top end of the job market, employers are competing for the same few candidates with impressive CVs and skills gained in college. The number of graduates hired by the UK's top employers rose 3.3% in 2015, with starting salaries remaining around £30,000 for the second year running. However, graduate pay at top law firms, investment banks, and accounting firms increased further.

A man suffered head and leg injuries when he fell in front of an oncoming train at Twickenham Station in London, UK. He was not critically injured, and the station was evacuated while he was treated. The cause of the fall is unknown, and investigations are ongoing. South West Trains services resumed after the incident.

Malta is an island located in the Mediterranean Sea, south of Sicily, and has a long history of colonial control. It has been occupied by various civilizations including Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, and later France and Britain. Malta gained independence from Britain in 1964 and became a popular tourist destination. The country's president is Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca, the youngest serving president in Malta's history, and Joseph Muscat is the prime minister. Many newspapers and broadcasters in Malta have strong political affiliations, and the country has a rich history including World War II and joining the European Union in 2004.

TIFF is hosting the world premiere of Jean-Marc Vallee's latest film, Demolition, starring Jake Gyllenhaal, Naomi Watts, Chris Cooper, and Judah Lewis. The film follows the story of a successful investment banker, who rebuilds his life after his wife is killed in a car crash. Vallee praised Gyllenhaal's performance, saying he went "everywhere, surprising me all the time." The film marks Vallee's third consecutive year at TIFF, following Dallas Buyers Club and Wild. Michael Moore's first film in six years, Where to Invade Next, is also premiering at the festival. Traditionally, TIFF is the start of awards season and has kicked off Oscar campaigns for past winners such as 12 Years a Slave, The King's Speech, Slumdog Millionaire, and American Beauty. Last year's People's Choice Award went to The Imitation Game.

The Belfast Telegraph leads with a story about a young boy who suffered burns from a petrol bomb attack in Newtownabbey, which has left him with scars from surgery. The Irish News reports on a controversy surrounding a Stormont scheme that awarded grants to five Orange Halls, with nationalists criticizing the distribution of funds. The Irish News also covers a County Tyrone boy fighting life-threatening epilepsy in the US and reports on demonstrations against President Trump's travel ban. The News Letter reports that a prosecution decision on a man connected to the Kingsmills massacre is imminent.

Action on Hearing Loss warns that listening to loud music for a long time can trigger tinnitus and affect hearing. One in 10 people in the UK are affected by tinnitus, with symptoms ranging from a "light buzzing" to a "constant roar" in the ears and head. The poll found that one in 10 people do not know what tinnitus is, with some thinking it is "big ears" or a "repetitive strain injury." Action on Hearing Loss is doing research into treatments and offers support to those affected by tinnitus. DJ Paul Oakenfold urges people to wear ear defenders to gigs and turn down music player volumes to prevent tinnitus.

France wins mixed team event over the United States, with Richard Gasquet and Kristina Mladenovic securing victory in the deciding doubles match. France's only previous Hopman Cup title was in 2014, with Alize Cornet and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga defeating Poland's Agnieszka Radwanska and Grzegorz Panfil. Great Britain's team, led by Dan Evans and Heather Watson, failed to advance past the group phase, losing to Switzerland, France, and Germany.

England coach Eddie Jones has said he can "feel" a long-seated rivalry towards England as they prepare to face Ireland at Twickenham on Saturday. Jones, who is not English but Australian, said he will be committed to England. He revealed he sees Leicester center Manu Tuilagi's future for England in the 12 shirt, but said he needs to be fully match fit. England is level with France at the top of the Six Nations table, ahead on points difference with both sides on six points after two games. Jones continued to insist his side was a "work in progress" and said his players have shown "commitment," "taking initiative" and "being independent." He is preparing England for an aerial bombardment from Ireland and said, "It has worked for them. It is not the way I think you should play rugby but it has been successful for them, so good luck."

Scottish Ambulance Service treated over 12,000 drunk patients in 6 months. Alcohol impacted operations, with over 50% of call-outs related to alcohol at weekends. NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde had the highest number of alcohol-related calls, followed by NHS Lothian and NHS Lanarkshire. Tory health spokesman said alcohol problem in Scottish society is "deep-rooted and complex," and personal responsibility is required. Scottish Ambulance Service spokesman said staff should not fear for their safety due to assaults related to alcohol. Public Health Minister Maureen Watt said Scotland is leading the way in UK in tackling alcohol misuse.

In Northern Ireland, 27% of working-age individuals are economically inactive, compared to the UK average of 22%. The new strategy, "Enabling Success," aims to boost employment rates by targeting individuals with work-limiting health conditions, lone parents, and those with caring commitments. The strategy involves 11 projects and is expected to help Northern Ireland reach the UK average employment rate by 2030.

Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump criticized John McCain, a former prisoner of war and 2008 presidential candidate, by saying he prefers people who were not captured. McCain's office criticized the comments as a new low in US politics. Trump later walked back his remarks but maintained that he does not consider McCain a hero because he has not taken care of veterans. Trump avoided military service due to deferments. Several Republican rivals and McCain's daughter criticized Trump's comments, and many other candidates lined up to attack him. There are currently 15 people running for the Republican presidential nomination, and Trump leads some polls. Analysts predict his appeal may wane as the contest develops.

Canadian author and Order of Canada recipient, W.P. Kinsella, passed away on Friday, with his agent revealing that his death was doctor-assisted. Kinsella was best known for his baseball-themed fantasy novel, "Shoeless Joe," which was adapted into the 1989 film "Field of Dreams" starring Kevin Costner. After a car crash, Kinsella lost interest in writing fiction but later resumed writing and his final work, "Russian Dolls," is set to be released in 2022.

Máiría Cahill, a member of one of Ireland's most prominent republican families, won a by-election to fill a vacant seat in the Irish Senate after Jimmy Harte of the Labour party resigned. Cahill, who previously accused an IRA member of raping her when she was 16 years old, won 122 of the 188 valid votes cast by serving senators and members of parliament. In 2014, the man she accused was prosecuted but later acquitted of all charges against him. Cahill has since distanced herself from the IRA and the dissident group Republican Network for Unity, and has vowed to use her time in the Senate to support victims of sexual abuse and to help engage young jobseekers in the country.

ChildLine launches campaign to combat "shocking" number of 12-year-olds addicted to porn. One Welsh boy says pornography makes him feel "perverted," and another worries it will affect his future marriage. NSPCC head of service in Wales warns against shying away from discussing the issue.

Mariner Street car park in Swansea will be replaced with a 725-bedroom student block, featuring a nightclub, gym, office space, bars, restaurants, and shops. The 22-story tower will be the second-tallest building in Swansea, next to Meridian Quay. Construction is expected to start later this year and finish by summer 2018. The planning committee report states that the tower will be a "bold addition to the city skyline" and that there is a growing need for student accommodation in Swansea. The project will also contribute to the regeneration of High Street.

Swathes of Queensland and New South Wales have been hit by floods caused by torrential rain and the remnants of Cyclone Debbie. Several rivers have broken their banks, prompting emergency warnings, and residents have used surfboards to paddle down the street. Businesses have been inundated, roads have been washed away, and trees have been brought down. Although it is too early to estimate a damage bill, tens of thousands of people have lost power. The severe weather has also washed away crops and caused other damage. Fortunately, the storm system has moved out to sea, leaving behind a trail of destruction.

American Airlines experienced a glitch on some of its flights on February 13, causing the iPad software used by pilots and co-pilots to stop working. The company had gone "paperless" in 2013 to save on fuel costs, and the software was intended to replace the need for paper flight plans. The cause of the glitch is still being investigated, and the company apologized for the inconvenience to passengers. Other airlines, including United Airlines and Delta, have also adopted iPads for their pilots and crew. The switch to electronic flight bags has also reduced flight preparation time and the likelihood of injuries, and offers real-time updates.

On Wednesday, a court in Thane convicted Girish Pote for the 2013 murder of his wife, Madhuvanti Pathak. Pote chopped his wife's body into pieces and confessed to the crime. The judge ruled that Pote will remain in jail for the rest of his life due to the "gruesome" nature of the murder. The couple had been fighting over money and Pathak wanted to return to France. They had a two-year-old son. Pote attacked his wife with a knife in Mumbai.

Bradford Council has proposed a one-way gyratory system to address the town's growing traffic congestion. The plan, to be displayed in June, involves a clockwise routing along East Parade, Hanover Street, and Cavendish Street. Deputy council leader Val Salter emphasized the urgency of addressing the issue.

Young footballer Thorpe, 23, has played for Rotherham United seven times this season. He last featured in a 5-2 defeat by Ipswich on 7 November. Thorpe may make his debut for Bradford against Millwall on Saturday. Bradford is currently seventh in League One, but outside the play-offs by goal difference.

A presenter on Radio Flaixbak pranked Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy by pretending to be Carles Puigdemont and securing a phone call with Rajoy. Rajoy agreed to meet with Puigdemont and was surprised when the presenter revealed it was a prank. Rajoy took the joke well and thanked the presenter. This is not the first time a high-profile figure has fallen for a prank phone call, as Tony Blair and Fidel Castro have also been pranked.

Lib Dem Baroness Hamwee raised concerns about the £1 pay rate for detainees at immigration removal centers in the UK, questioning whether it was something that society could be proud of. Baroness Williams of Trafford, a government minister, defended the voluntary work program, arguing that it helped meet the "recreational and intellectual needs" of detainees and was not designed to save money. However, Lord Rosser pointed to a Freedom of Information request from 2014 that suggested hundreds of detainees had been paid more than £45,000 for work at immigration centers, and asked who benefited from the apparent savings. Lady Williams maintained that the work was not about supplementing contractors, but former Commons Speaker Lady Boothroyd pressed for an answer to the original question of who benefits from the program. Lady Williams replied that the money was not wages as the ordinary working population would understand it and was being reviewed.

The Walter Scott Prize will announce its winner at the Borders Book Festival in Melrose later this year. Seven authors are in the running for the 25,000 prize, including Jo Baker, Sebastian Barry, Charlotte Hobson, Hannah Kent, Francis Spufford, Graham Swift, and Rose Tremain. The judges extended the list to seven titles due to the "variety of the longlist" and said the shortlisted novels offer "joy in the discovery of unusual subjects and times" as well as a "visceral connection" with their characters. The winner will receive 25,000 and each shortlisted author will receive 1,000.

Bangladesh need 33 runs to win their first Test against England, who have only two wickets left. England were bowled out for 240 in their second innings, followed by a response of 253-8, before play was ended due to bad light. The match has seen a record number of decisions reviewed, with tension on the field adding to the excitement of Test cricket. England's tour of Bangladesh continues with the second Test starting on Friday, followed by a five-Test series against India in November.

Members of the University and College Union (UCU) in Scotland have voted to take strike action over job security at the University of Aberdeen's medical school. The UCU claims that three-quarters of those who participated in a ballot voted for strike action, and a petition will also be handed in on Tuesday. The university has expressed disappointment at the announcement, and stated that all four members of staff now at the center of the dispute are of Asian ethnic origin, which raises the question of whether the process was discriminatory. The university says it has made arrangements to ensure that students' exams are not disrupted, and that no compulsory redundancies will be needed.

A man named Jay Brenton Liptrot owned the property in Prestatyn, Denbighshire where five people, including his tenant Lee-Ann Shiers and her family, died in a fire in October 2012. Liptrot did not enter a plea at his court appearance on Friday, and another person, Melanie Smith, has already been sentenced to at least 30 years in prison for starting the fire in a dispute over a shared hallway. Liptrot will appear at Mold Crown Court in May.

At the Aberdeen Sea Cadets base, a 34-year old man was arrested for an incident deemed "disgraceful" by Police Scotland. The Crown Office later released the man from custody pending further inquiries.

New report reveals the negative impact of falling behind with reading at a young age. The "Read On. Get On." coalition aims to increase literacy rates, with 11-year-olds reading well within a generation, and urges parents to read to young children for 10 minutes a day. The report finds that children from low-income families have fewer books at home and are less likely to be read to, which impacts their reading skills later in life. The coalition expects the number of poor children living in poverty in Scotland to rise, but believes that with the nation's support, every child can have a fair chance to learn to read well within a generation.

The Belfast Giants have signed 30-year-old forward Martin Garside and 28-year-old forward Mark Garside for the upcoming season. Martin Garside has committed to the Giants for an eighth year in a row, while Mark Garside has signed a new contract after spending four years with the Edinburgh Capitals. Head Coach Adam Keefe is excited to have both players on board and expects them to play key roles in the Giants' chase for silverware, particularly with their experience in winning league championships and the recent World Championship gold.

16-year-old Rasmus Barlow was reported missing on Monday and a large-scale search was conducted by police. His death is not being treated as suspicious, and a file is being prepared for the coroner's office. Support for the teenager's family is being provided by police.

Regina Hungerford, a 55-year-old teacher, was found guilty of striking a 17-year-old student in her classroom at Merthyr Tydfil College. She previously had a conviction for common assault overturned, claiming she slammed a notebook on a desk, but this was deemed unacceptable by the Education Workforce Council. The panel ruled that Hungerford acted in breach of teaching principles and her conduct put the public trust in the profession at risk. The panel concluded that she did make physical contact with the student on the head or hand.

On May 4th, also known as Star Wars Day, many big brands and celebrities are using the hashtag #MayThe4thBeWithYou to promote their products and services. Mark Hamill, reprising his role as Luke Skywalker, posed with his children for a special family portrait. Darth Vader himself has also joined in the fun, and many global brands are using the hashtag to sell flight tickets, pizzas, and camper vans. The British Museum is being praised for using an actual Star Wars exhibit to celebrate the day, and former Dragons Den star Theo Paphitis has also joined in the fun. Heathrow Airport is winning praise for its funny tweet featuring the Millennium Falcon and X-wing starfighters. While some charities are using the hashtag to raise awareness for their respective charities, for others, every day is Star Wars Day.

Retired generals and admirals endorse Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump for having the right temperament to be commander-in-chief. Trump rejects claims of impropriety over political donation to Florida official and praises support from veterans. Four-star generals believe Trump is more trustworthy than Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, citing hollowing out of military and global threats. Trump and Clinton to participate in national security forum, with Clinton releasing campaign ad featuring veterans critical of Trump. Trump has faced criticism from military members, including casting doubt on war hero John McCain's credentials.

21 year old left-sided player joins Barnsley from QPR following promotion to Championship. Had brief loan spell at Colchester in 2014-15. Signs one year contract with option for another year at Colchester.

Phillip Pullman has announced a new trilogy called "The Book of Dust," with the first novel to be released in October 2017. The new series will focus on the story of Lyra Belacqua and her adventures, starting from when she is a baby and ending when she is 20 years old. The first book's title has not yet been released. Pullman's "His Dark Materials" trilogy sold over 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages.

An American Red Cross safety poster depicting a racially biased scene, featuring more black children being "not cool" and more white children being "cool," has sparked controversy. The poster was quickly removed after being criticized, and the American Red Cross issued a statement apologizing for any offense caused. The Salida Pool and Recreation Department also responded to the initial tweet, but the reaction online has continued.

Karl Robinson will remain as MK Dons manager next season, according to chairman Peter Winkelman. Winkelman stated that Robinson wants to continue managing the club and has a better understanding of the club after experiencing relegation. Winkelman also acknowledged mistakes were made with recruitment, but is confident in Robinson's ability to lead the team and become a bigger club in League One next season.

James Cosmo and Karen Gillan, Scottish actors known for films like "Braveheart" and "Doctor Who," have been named as honorary patrons of the Edinburgh International Film Festival, with Cosmo expressing gratitude and Gillan excited to celebrate Scottish and international filmmaking.

Tottenham's left-back, Danny Rose, made comments in the media stating that he and his teammates feel underpaid and that the club should sign more well-known players. He later apologized for his "ill-judged" timing and said that he and his teammate Kieran Trippier's injury are not as bad as first feared. However, Tottenham has not signed any new players this summer, and sold their right-back Kyle Walker to Manchester City for £45m. The club's manager, Mauricio Pochettino, stated that Rose has a future at the club and that the team is moving on.

The International Ski Federation (FIS) imposed a ban on Singapore-born British violinist Vanessa Vanakorn, who competed for Thailand at the Sochi Olympics, for helping to manipulate results to qualify for the Games. The ban was imposed after an investigation into four Slovenian races before the January qualification deadline. The Court of Arbitration for Sport will now consider an appeal filed by Vanakorn.

In a League Two match, Macclesfield Town took an early lead in the seventh minute through Rhys Browne's goal, but the game remained 1-0 at halftime as both sides created chances. In the second half, Macclesfield nearly doubled their lead, but the goal was ruled out due to an offside flag. Eastleigh nearly equalized in the 70th minute, but Ayo Obileye's header clattered against the post. The match ended with Macclesfield winning 1-0.

The cast of The Big Bang Theory, including Jim Parsons, Johnny Galecki, Kaley Cuoco, Simon Helberg, and Kunal Nayyar, have yet to reach an agreement with Warner Bros TV over salaries. If a deal is not reached in the next two weeks, production may be delayed. Despite the ongoing negotiations, the show is expected to continue and potentially extend beyond its current contract. The cast members are reportedly seeking salaries of up to $1 million per episode, which would make them the highest paid actors on US television, surpassing Ashton Kutcher and Jon Cryer from Two and a Half Men.
