Alexander Worth died in a car crash on an access road between Newlyns and Lodge Farms at North Warnborough. The driver, Matthew Cobden, only spoke to confirm his identity and was taken to hospital with serious injuries. The court heard that no other vehicles were involved in the incident and that Alexander was the only fatality. The case has been referred to Winchester Crown Court for 26 July. District Judge Philip Gillibrand offered his sympathy to Alexander's family and praised their courage.

Refugees in Wales called for concrete action to help those displaced by war in Syria. Welsh Refugee Council's Hannah Wharf welcomed UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians in the UK. Minister Paul Martin called it a serious human-made disaster. First Minister Carwyn Jones will hold a summit on the refugee crisis next week. Local authorities in Wales are willing to help but need financial support.

Jhon Jairo Velasquez, known as Popeye, was a top hit man for Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar. He confessed to killing 300 people and may have been involved in up to 3,000 more. He recently walked free from prison after serving 20 years, under heavy police escort. Some victims believe he still has not paid for his crimes, while others believe it's time to give him a second chance. Velasquez was convicted for his role in the murder of presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan in 1989, and later turned state's witness against former Justice Minister Alberto Santofimio, who was convicted of ordering Galan's killing. Santofimio was a close associate of Escobar and drug cartel leader in a war against the Colombian state.

Warrington Wolves' Kurt Gidley became the first rugby league player to wear a camera during a match on October 13. The device was mounted on a vest behind a hole in Gidley's shirt to give viewers a unique perspective of the contact sport. However, the camera was removed at half-time due to technical issues. Coach Tony Smith said that Gidley wanted to get on with playing footy and the camera did not affect his performance. The camera experiment was not used as an excuse for the team's poor performance, which has not won a game in five successive defeats. Sky Sports plans to continue with the experiment and review the game to give it another try.

Police were called to Auchinlee care home in Campbeltown on Tuesday regarding alleged sexual offences involving an 82-year-old man and a 76-year-old woman. The Care Inspectorate is monitoring the situation, and anyone with concerns about a care home can contact their helpline. The spokeswoman for Police Scotland confirmed that the man is the subject of a report to the procurator fiscal.

Des McDaid, who was sexually abused at the Clontarf orphanage in Perth, Australia, and at the St Joseph's Home in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, gave evidence to the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry. He described brutality and sexual abuse by Christian Brothers and a lay teacher at the Clontarf home, and by older boys at the St Joseph's Home. McDaid was one of 16 children shipped to Australia in 1953 and is still in contact with his mother who apologized to him upon their reunion. The inquiry is examining the experiences of 50 child migrants from Northern Ireland, including oral and written evidence.

World number 45 Edmund lost to reigning US Open champion Wawrinka in straight sets, 6-7 (2-7) 6-4 6-4. Wawrinka broke serve twice in the decider, with the match lasting two hours 36 minutes. Swiss third seed Kei Nishikori will play Wawrinka in the semi-finals. Canadian top seed and defending champion Raonic beat 14-time Grand Slam champion Nadal 4-6 6-3 6-4, while Bulgarian seventh seed Dimitrov beat Austrian Thiem to also reach the semi-finals. British number four Aljaz Bedene was knocked out in straight sets by French fifth seed Paire in the Chennai Open.

The 50-year-old musician is being treated at a neurosurgery clinic in Munich for an undisclosed condition. The band U2's US tour date on June 3 has been postponed, and the band's appearance at Glastonbury Festival on June 25 may be in doubt. U2's tour, the 360 Degree tour, earned $109m in 2009, making it the most profitable tour of the year. The band's manager, Paul McGuinness, is working to reschedule the tour's remaining dates.

Two people and a pilot were taken to the hospital after a small aircraft experienced a fuel leak between Abergavenny and Raglan. The incident happened at 15:25 BST and the road was closed with South Wales fire engines on the scene. The crew was able to stop the fuel leak.

Mrs. Angela Scott appointed as new Chief Executive of Aberdeen City Council, replacing Valerie Watts. She is stepping up from her current position as Director of Corporate Governance. Council leader Barney Crockett states that Mrs. Scott is perfectly suited to use her financial expertise and leadership skills to help the administration deliver on its promises to the city. She is proud to accept the job and is looking forward to working hard with elected members and key partners to deliver on Aberdeen's priorities. The salary will be Â£144,685.

Manchester United's full-back options are limited after Luke Shaw, Marcos Rojo, Ashley Young, Antonio Valencia, Phil Jones, and Guillermo Varela all suffered injuries. Cameron Borthwick-Jackson and Donald Love are the only fit full-backs, with Love making his first-team debut during the game. This leaves Van Gaal with few options, as he must line up a 13-year-old player or someone else. United's 26-year-old full-back, Darmian, started the game against Sunderland but suffered a dislocated shoulder, leaving him out for several weeks.

Kenneth Harper, 33, was convicted of sex crimes and assault in 2021. The Court of Criminal Appeal in Edinburgh quashed his convictions for two rape charges after defense arguments about mutual corroboration. He was given a three-year sentence for the remaining offenses. Solicitor advocate John Keenan challenged the rape convictions, which were based on mutual corroboration. The appeal court ruled that there was a long lapse of time between the two alleged offenses and no special features linking them. The court found that the similarities between the two incidents were not compelling enough to infer a course of conduct.

The Great Train Robbery: A Copper's Tale, a drama about the 1963 heist, will feature Luke Evans as its lead and Michael Broadbent as Tommy Butler, a retired police officer who led the investigation. Broadbent is excited to play the "fascinating copper of the old school." Chris Chibnall, the show's executive producer and writer, calls Broadbent's casting a "dream piece of casting." The heist resulted in several robbers receiving lengthy sentences, and the drama will air later this year.

A Lithuanian schoolgirl was left bruised in a brawl in Central Park in Peterborough on Friday evening. The attack was filmed by the girl's mother and posted on social media, which has since been viewed more than 680,000 times. The police are investigating the incident, which was reported to them. The girl told the BBC that she was attacked by a group of about 20 or 25 girls because they thought she was "being cheeky" to some of them at school. The video of the brawl showed a girl being pushed to the ground and repeatedly kicked. The incident happened between 20:00 and 21:00 BST, and Cambridgeshire Police is looking into the matter.

The Maccabees scored a number one album in the UK with Marks To Prove It, beating out Lianne La Havas by just 1,300 chart sales. Cilla Black's music charted following her death, with The Very Best of Cilla Black reaching its highest chart position in 51 years. Calvin Harris and Disciples' "How Deep Is Your Love" climbed to number two, while Little Mix's "Black Magic" fell to number three. Years & Years' "Shine" finished in fifth place.

One Direction members continue as a four-piece after Zayn Malik's departure for personal reasons. Liam Payne thanks fans for their support, and the band continues their On the Road Again tour. The European leg of the tour starts in Cardiff with two concerts on June 5-6. Zayn Malik is said to be working on a solo album. Fans are encouraged to follow the band's social media accounts for updates.

Police Scotland are investigating a leak of information regarding an alleged gun crime, with witnesses' names and details posted on social media. Inquiries are ongoing to determine the full circumstances.

Steven Flynn broke into St Johnstone's stadium, McDiarmid Park, with a crowbar, trying to find money to pay off drug debts. Flynn opened a door onto the pitch and walked around the stadium until police left. He stole keys and a charity cash box containing 20 pounds. Flynn was jailed for 16 months after admitting the break-in.

UKIP candidate, Victoria Ayling, is campaigning in Sleaford and North Hykeham constituency ahead of a by-election on Thursday. UKIP leader, Nigel Farage, is supporting the candidate and appeared in a poster with an incorrect 'n' spelling of Hykeham. Social media users have pointed out the error, but the BBC has not yet received a response from UKIP. The seat was vacated by Conservative MP, Stephen Phillips, due to policy differences with the government.

Stirling County fell behind in the opening minute of their Scottish National League match against Albion Rovers after a mistake by their goalkeeper resulted in a goal for the hosts. Despite creating chances, Stirling were unable to score an equalizer as their opponent's defense held strong. Just before halftime, Stirling's Brian Martin was sent off for handling the ball in the penalty area, giving Albion Rovers a chance to score from the penalty spot, but the striker Sean Dickson missed the shot. The match ended with Albion Rovers victorious, 1-0.

Fiona Barnes, who also faked terminal cancer, was jailed for 15 months for the theft from Preston's Space Centre and perverting the course of justice. She was ordered to pay back £1 at a Proceeds of Crime hearing, as she had no money to her name. The Centre said the ruling was "outrageous" and a "complete insult". Barnes stole £24,713 from the Space Centre in 2012 and tried to cover her tracks by faking documents indicating the centre had won non-existent grants of up to £800,000. After her sentence, the Centre was bought out by Creative Support, based in Manchester, securing its future. The Space Centre, which supports children with physical, learning or emotional difficulties, is the UK's largest multi-sensory environment.

Former Bristol City defender Adam El-Abd has joined Shrewsbury Town manager Micky Mellon's rebuilding squad ahead of the upcoming League One season. The 31-year-old started his career at Brighton & Hove Albion and clocked up over 300 appearances for the club over nearly 11 years. He joined Ashton Gate in January 2014 and had loan spells with Bury, Swindon and Gillingham before being released by Bristol City at the end of the 2017-2018 season. El-Abd will join former Bury full-back Joe Riley at Shrewsbury as Mellon continues to build his squad.

England rugby coach Eddie Jones believes his team needs more consistent leaders if they are to win the 2019 World Cup. He said they currently have a "small and good group" but need to develop more leaders. Jones also highlighted the importance of playmakers Owen Farrell and Dylan Hartley, who will captain the team in the Six Nations.

A Range Rover crashed into a property on Hearthcote Road in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, at around 2:00 am. Two people were forced to leave their home due to structural damage, and an investigation has been launched. Witnesses are appealed to. The road was closed for an hour, and no one was arrested. One driver suffered minor injuries, but did not require hospitalization.

In 2015, work began to bring down a building on Kingsway, which was due to take six months. However, more asbestos was found than expected, resulting in the outer structure still standing. The demolition is part of the council's plan to transform Kingsway into a business district. The demolition is scheduled to finish by the spring.

Rovers trailed 2-1 when a goal by Grant Hanley crossed the line, but the effort was later hacked clear by Jamie O'Hara. Referee Tony Harrington did not award the goal, and Bowyer urged the Football League to adopt goal-line technology like the Premier League. Bowyer believes technology will make the game better and improve rewards. Media playback is not supported. Fulham manager Kit Symons supports goal-line technology.

Poland international and 19-year-old midfielder Jakub "Kuba" Kapustka has joined English Premier League champions Leicester City for a reported £7.5m, signing a five-year deal. The youngster impressed at Euro 2016, playing in four of Poland's five matches en route to the quarterfinals. He joins Leicester ahead of a friendly against Barcelona in Stockholm. Kapustka is the fifth summer signing for manager Claudio Ranieri following the acquisitions of goalkeeper Ron-Robert Zieler, defender Luis Hernandez, midfielder Nampalys Mendy, and forward Ahmed Musa. Fans can stay informed by subscribing to the BBC Sport newsletter for news, features, and videos.

The Burrell Collection will close on Sunday for a multi-million pound redevelopment and reopen in 2020. This weekend, the museum is hosting free activities, and only a fifth of the collection is currently on display. The collection was donated by collector Sir William Burrell in 1944, and estimates suggest the project will cost between £60m and £66m. The renovation will include a new roof and energy-efficient design. Some works from the collection will be displayed at Kelvingrove Museum and Art Gallery during the renovation. The first exhibition, "Burrell at Kelvingrove: Joseph Crawhall," will showcase 23 works by the Glasgow Boys.

Hundreds of farmers who supply chickens to a poultry processing company are recipients of the heating subsidy, which has raised concerns among farmers and the finance minister. The subsidy is used to heat buildings where chicks are housed, and many farmers have replaced LPG heating systems with wood chip boilers. The finance minister held a meeting with officials and the company, but the company made no reference to concerns about the operation of the scheme. The company aims to secure the Northern Ireland RHI scheme within budget, and advocates responsible use of heat. However, cost control proposals were submitted and then withdrawn. The finance minister is seeking a solution to the RHI scandal that is not a "botched" one.
